awd_titl_txt: Exploring Computation Integrated into Technology and Engineering (ExCITE)
awd_abstract_narration:
The International Technology and Engineering Educators Association (ITEEA) proposes a project--Exploring Computation Integrated into Technology and Engineering (ExCITE)--to prepare high school technology and engineering (T&E) teachers to teach computer science (CS) and computational thinking (CT) in their classrooms. The project will leverage the NSF-funded Beauty and Joy of Computing (BJC), an Advanced Placement CS Principles course, enhancing it with real-world, hands-on problem-solving challenges to increase student engagement and better suit the design-based pedagogy employed by T&E and many Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) teachers.  It will design and implement a professional development (PD) program that prepares and supports T&E teachers in teaching this enhanced course. The course, BJC-T&E, will be offered as part of the ITEEA's flagship Engineering by Design (EbD) national curriculum, which will significantly broaden participation in CS and CT for a large cohort of students (and their teachers) and expand access to BJC-T&E to diverse populations nationwide.

ExCITE will employ a Research Practitioner Partnership (RPP) that includes CS faculty from North Carolina State University and Boston College, researchers and T&E curriculum experts from Hofstra University's Center for STEM Research, and state education departments and local school districts in Maryland and Virginia. The RPP framework ensures that all stakeholders have been fully engaged in the development and implementation of the PD and research and evaluation program. Through a full spectrum of PD workshops with follow-on support, ExCITE will prepare 190 T&E educators from geographically, socioeconomically, racially, and ethnically diverse regions to effectively integrate CS and CT into high school T&E curricula. ExCITE's RPP will use a Design-Based Implementation Research model, initially investigating two research questions: (RQ1) How can a PD program be designed and optimized to support high school T&E teachers in learning and effectively teaching BJC-T&E? and (RQ2) To what extent and under what conditions does the integration of CS skills into T&E using design-based real-world problems broaden participation of districts, teachers, and students, particularly those who do not normally adopt, teach or enroll in CS courses?  The project will also include an evaluation that will document and assess the organization and functioning of the RPP, the PD implementation, revisions to the PD model, classroom testing, and dissemination of outcomes and research results.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
OVERVIEW

 Exploring Computation Integrated into Technology and Engineering (ExCITE) was an NSF CSforAll: RPP medium scale, high school strand project.  The leadership comprised the International Technology and Engineering Education Association (a national teacher professional association) (ITEEA), Hofstra University, researchers from North Carolina State University and Boston College, subject matter experts, and an external evaluator, in partnership with state and local supervisors and classroom teachers in multiple school districts in Maryland and Virginia. The Project enhanced the NSF-funded Beauty and Joy of Computing (BJC) curriculum with the integration of real-world heads-on, hands-on problem-based design challenges to ensure that the resulting curriculum (AP Computer Science Principles by Design) is consistent with the pedagogic approaches of high school Technology and Engineering teachers. The Project trained 18 T&E Teachers in two phases in MD and VA. The 18 teachers implemented the curriculum with 720 students in the 2020-21 and 2021-22 school year.  In the summer of the final year, the Project worked with the state DOEs in MD and VA to create two in-state AP CSP by Design training teams.  These teams trained a further 29 T&E teachers MD and VA in the summer of 2022 and 2023.

 INTELLECTUAL MERIT

 The mission of ExCITE was to implement a replicable model to expand CS participation by providing pedagogically sound AP CSP instruction for T&E students nationwide. The use of State-level RPPs ensured that project created a scalable framework to recruit T&E HS teachers in MD and VA.  The Project used the BJC curriculum, enhanced with added hands-on computer-control design challenges, resulting in the AP Computer Science by Design (AP CSP by Design) curriculum. The PD program engaged district and high school leadership, as well as T&E teachers in a comprehensive PD and support program, The Project was led by distinguished educators and disciplinary experts who have long been at the forefront of the CSforAll movement, in partnership with the T&E national professional association (ITEEA) leadership.

BROADER IMPACTS

There are approximately 30,000 T&E teachers in the United States who teach students in almost every school district. T&E is central to the delivery of STEM teaching and learning. Its design-based teaching methodology is multifaceted, encourages generation of creative alternatives, and rejects one-size-fits-all approaches. This pedagogy resonates well with female and male students from diverse backgrounds, including those from underserved and underrepresented populations and those who might not previously self-identified as computer science students. The offering of AP CSP by Design as part of the ITEEA’s flagship Engineering by Design (EbD © ITEEA) national curriculum has significantly broadened participation in CS and CT for a large cohort of students (and their teachers) and has expanded access to BJC-T&E to diverse populations nationwide. ExCITE has add a significant new dimension to T&E teaching and learning and to the STEM education delivery system, resulting in more students becoming engaged and competent in CS and CT. The AP CSP by Design curriculum resides on an open-access website hosted by ITEEA. ITEEA will sustain Project PD activities as well as the Community of Practice forum through continuing outreach and advocacy after the conclusion of the NSF funding cycle.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/19/2023
Modified by: Anthony T Gordon
